He also said:ğŸ”½I am distressed because I have no compassionate mind, unlike that elephant.
Is it because this female elephant spoke ill of you and disturbed you that you are crying?
She replied:
She did not speak ill of me or disturb me, but because of her great compassion and virtue.
I harmed you with an evil mind and a poisoned arrow, but you, out of compassion, were afraid for the other elephants and saw me as a threat, covering me with your belly.
It is because of this that my mind is troubled and I am crying out of fear.
She then spoke a verse, saying:
I now harmed the elephant king's body with a poisoned arrow,
but you, with your compassionate virtue, have wounded my heart.
A wounded mind is difficult to heal, but now you have wounded my virtue,
and the wound in my foolish mind is hard to restore.
Your virtue is like the great ocean, who can say it can be exhausted?
Comfort, compassion, and protection, if spoken of and said,
Although my form is human, I have no virtue of compassion at all,
Empty existence is like a corpse, worse than an animal,
With a form resembling a human, yet committing evil worse than an animal.
Although you have received an animal body, in morality and virtue you are supreme among humans,
Although your form is not human, in morality and virtue you are indeed human.
The Bodhisattva elephant king asked the hunter,
You must answer me quickly!
What is it that you have come to shoot me for?
The hunter replied,
I was sent by the king to take a small part of your body, not out of my own mind to harm you.
The elephant king answered,
Take what you need quickly.
At that time the elephant king spoke a verse, saying:
If you need anything, stretch out your hand and take it quickly.
Those who give rise to the bodhisattva mind have nothing they are unwilling to give up.
Whatever you need, I will give it all to you.
If you need tusks, I will give you my tusks. Take them as you wish.
I have attained this form through saving and rescuing others.
I have given up everything. Take what you need as you wish.
For those who benefit themselves, they can quickly reach nirvana.
For the sake of all beings, I take on a body in the three realms.
For the sake of omniscience, I use compassion and rescue as the cause.
The hunter felt ashamed and said this:
I was sent by the king to come and take your tusks.
The elephant king replied:
Take them as you wish, do not hesitate.
The hunter replied:
I really cannot pull out your tusks.
He then spoke a verse, saying:
Your mind of kindness is full, I fear you, the father of kindness.
If I pull out your tusks, my hands will surely fall off.
At that time, the elephant king said to the hunter:
If you are afraid, I will pull it out for you.
Having said this, he wrapped his trunk around the tusk, and after a long time, he pulled it out, and the elephant king's blood flowed out a lot. He then spoke a verse, saying:
Blood flows from the place where the tusk is pulled out, flowing down from the shoulder,
The elephant king's great blessings and virtues, as white as a lotus flower,
Like a pile of jasmine flowers, piled up into a large heap,
At that time, those piles of flowers, as white as the elephant king's body,
Also like a large rocky mountain, covered with white snow on top,
Like the top of a high mountain, red liquid flowing down.
At that time, the elephant king, trembling in pain, still comforted himself.
At that time, a god then spoke a verse, saying:
The mind should be firmly settled, do not be foolish and depressed,
One should contemplate the suffering masses, how can they be saved?
The world is all subject to death, you should rescue and deliver them,
You should hold firm resolve, do not give rise to a sorrowful mind.
Devas, humans, asuras, gandharvas, yakshas,
Filled the sky, praising and speaking of the unprecedented.
The devas said:
In the past, it was extremely rare, able to do difficult and painful things.
Experiencing pain now, the inner mind turns towards enlightenment,
Seeking the supreme fruit, there is never a thought of turning back.
Another deva said to that deva:
Such a bodhisattva will never turn back.
And spoke a verse, saying:
Knowing the suffering of pulling out a child's tooth, having compassion for the hells.
At that time, the elephant king, having pulled out the tusks, silently remained still.
At that time, the hunter thought like this:
Having pulled out the tusks and placed them on the ground, will he regret it and
Not give them to me?
The elephant king, knowing his thoughts, comforted him and spoke together, then spoke a verse, saying:
My tusks are like jasmine flowers, also like white lotus roots,
I give you all six tusks, the best of all tusks,
I give them to you to make you feel at ease.
Gradually make the pain stop, and make me towards you,
Obtain a respectful and reverent mind.
I am an extremely evil person, killing, stealing, lusting, and deceiving you,
Full of deceit and unwholesomeness.
You can do many evil things, with a harmful mind as your bow and sharp arrows,
I will all forget and not remember, only remembering to respect the kasaya robe,
Seeing it, my mind will be respectful and believing.
There is purity and impurity, I am now the patron,
Fully endowed with purity, waiting for me to manage my mind,
To make the karmic retribution vast, and then I will give to you.
At that time, the elephant king said to the hunter:
This kasaya is the banner of detachment. I respect and look up to it with a reverent mind.
He lifted the tusk with his nose and gave it to the hunter, then spoke a verse, saying:
I now speak the truth. An arrow shot my body,
But I have not the slightest resentment, nor will I retaliate with evil.
By the cause of this truth, I will quickly realize enlightenment,
And deliver all sentient beings from such suffering and distress.
Having spoken this verse, he then gave his tusks to the hunter.
For what reason did he draw this analogy?

In countless hundreds of thousands of past lives, he always made such difficult sacrifices, made vows to fulfill his wishes, to make all sentient beings who suffered attain their original path, to make people understand, to keep their minds pure and give rise to faith and respect. For this reason, he drew this analogy.
Furthermore, the great beings, the bodhisattvas, do not spare their lives for the sake of sentient beings.
I once heard that in the Himalayas, there were two kings of deer, each leading five hundred deer, eating grass in the mountains.
At that time, in the city of Varanasi, there was a king named Brahmadatta. The king went to the Himalayas and sent people to set up a fence around the snow mountains.
Then all the deer fell into the encirclement, with no place to go for refuge or escape, and not a single deer could escape.
At that time, the king of the deer had a multicolored body like a mosaic of precious treasures.
What expedient can be used to save the deer from this calamity?
He further thought:
There is no other plan, only to go straight to the king.
Having thought this, he went straight to the king.
When the king saw him, he ordered his attendants:
Be careful not to harm him. Let him come as he pleases.
At that time, the king of deer went to the king and said these words:
Great king!
Do not kill the herd of deer for amusement and use it as entertainment, do not do this.
May the king have compassion and release the herd of deer, do not let them be harmed.
The king said to the king of deer:
I need deer meat to eat.
The king of deer replied:
If the king needs meat, I will offer one deer every day.
If the king kills them all at once, the meat will surely go bad and cannot be kept for long. Take one deer a day, the deer will multiply, and the king will not lack meat.
The king immediately agreed.
At that time, the Bodhisattva deer king said to the king of deer Devadatta:
I will now go with you, send out one deer every day to provide for the king's food. I will send out one deer today, and you will send out one deer tomorrow.
They made an agreement to send out the deer in turn for many days.
Later, at one time, Devadatta's deer king let out a doe who was pregnant and about to give birth. She pleaded with Devadatta, saying:
I will die now, but I dare not entrust it. I must wait until I give birth. I have no regrets about offering it to the kitchen.
At that time, the deer king did not listen to her words:
You should just go now. Who will replace you?
He became angry.
At that time, the doe, having been scolded with anger, thought like this:
That deer king is extremely compassionate. I should go to him and ask for the life of my child to be spared.
Having had this thought, she went to the bodhisattva, knelt on her front knees facing the bodhisattva deer king, and fully explained the matter to the deer king, speaking a verse:
I now have no savior. I only pray that you will rescue me.
There are many sentient beings. I am now alone, frightened and cramped.
Please have compassion and pity, and save me from this suffering and difficulty.
I have no one else to rely on, I can only come and take refuge in you.
You always delight in benefiting and bringing peace and happiness to all beings.
If I were to die now, both lives would be lost.
I now wish to save my unborn child and let it have a complete life.
When the Bodhisattva Deer King heard these verses, he asked the doe:
Have you already told the king yourself?
The doe replied:
I have gone to him, but he did not listen to my words. He only saw me as an object of anger and reproach. Who can take your place?
She then spoke a verse, saying:
He saw me as an object of anger and reproach, without any thought of saving and pitying.
He ordered me to quickly go there. Who can take your place?
I now take refuge in you, one whose essence is compassion.
Therefore, you should let me escape with my life.
The Bodhisattva Deer King said to the deer,
Do not worry, you may go as you please. I will think it over myself.
When the deer heard this, he was overjoyed and returned to his herd.
The Bodhisattva Deer King had this thought:
If I send other deer, they will say:
'I am not yet due to go, why do you send me?'
Having had this thought, his mind was enlightened, and he spoke a verse, saying:ğŸ”½I will now go myself
to the king's kitchen,
I vow to surely save all sentient beings.ğŸ”½If I can use my own life
to ransom the lives of mosquitoes and ants,
even if I do this, there will still be great benefit.ğŸ”½The reason for keeping this body
is precisely for the sake of saving others,ğŸ”½if I can save one life,
I would give up my body as if it were grass or a pebble.
Having spoken this verse, he gathered the herd of deer he led and said, If there is anything I have not done for you, let me repent.
I wish to abandon you and take the place of another's life, and go to the king's kitchen.
At that time, when the deer heard this, they all grieved and said,
May the king not go, we will go in his place.
The deer king replied,
I have made a vow and will go myself. If I send you, you will surely be distressed, but now I am joyful and have no displeasure.
He then spoke a verse, saying:
Abandoning the body without being free from desire, one will certainly have a place of rebirth.
Now I will save them, abandoning the body will certainly be superior.
I now know this body will certainly decay,
Now, for the sake of saving and pitying, it is truly abandoning the body for the Dharma.
For one who attains being a cause for the Dharma, how could one not be joyful?
At that time, the deer used various admonitions and analogies, and finally became exhausted, unable to make him stop.

The kitchen supervisor who had seen the deer king before immediately recognized him and went to inform the king, saying that the deer king had come to the kitchen by himself.
When the king heard these words, he came out in person to where the deer king was.
The king said to him:
Are your deer all gone?
Why have you come yourself?
The deer king replied:
It is because of the king's protection that the deer have more than doubled.
The reason I came is for a pregnant doe. I want to take her place and go to the king's kitchen myself.
He then spoke a verse, saying:
If one wishes to seek something, it is not enough to fulfill one's mind.
If I am able to do it, but do not do it,
what is the difference from a piece of wood?
Abandoning this foul-smelling body, it will surely become empty and ruined,
without doing even a hair's breadth of good.
This body will surely return to destruction. Abandoning oneself, others will be completely saved, and I will attain great benefit.
At that time, King Brahmadatta, having heard these words, his body hair all stood on end, and he immediately spoke a verse, saying:
I am a human with the form of a deer, you are a deer with the form of a human,
Endowed with merit is a human, the remainder of evil is an animal.
Alas, there is a wise one, alas, there is a courageous one,
Alas, one who is able to have compassion and save sentient beings.
You have made this resolve and form, which is precisely teaching me.
You may now return, along with the herd of deer,
Do not give rise to thoughts of fear.
I now make a vow never to eat the flesh of any deer again.
At that time the king of deer said to the king:
If the king wishes to show compassion, he should go himself to where the herd of deer is and personally comfort them, granting them freedom from fear.
When the king heard these words, he went himself to the forest, to where the herd of deer was, and granted the deer freedom from fear. He then spoke a verse, saying:
Within my kingdom, to all the herds of deer,
I will firmly protect them, do not give rise to fear.
This forest of mine, as well as the springs and ponds,
I give them all to the deer, and no longer permit killing and harming.
Therefore, this forest is named the Deer Park.
